reinforcements.similarity: Both identify phase transitions as critical trust gates requiring System 1 approval before System 2 engagement
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Guest works-001 addresses rescheduling policy signifiers during search/evaluation/negotiation. Host works-001 addresses continuity priming during discovery/evaluation/onboarding. Both cite Kahneman's associative coherence principle and recognize that each new screen/interaction triggers automatic legitimacy assessment. Pattern: anchor with familiar before introducing new.
reinforcements.recommendation: merge - Consolidate into single cross-journey element titled 'System 1 Trust Gate at Every Phase Transition' covering both guest and host journeys with phase-specific applications

reinforcements.similarity: Both recognize ego depletion and design for depleted users after initial phases
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Guest works-002 addresses immediate feedback for asynchronous negotiation. Host works-002 addresses designing for depleted users after evaluation call. Both cite Kahneman's ego depletion research and parole judge study. Guest applies to crisis rescheduling (depleted by schedule conflict stress), host applies to listing wizard (depleted by evaluation call effort). Pattern: reduce decisions, provide smart defaults, allow save/resume.
reinforcements.recommendation: keep_both - Contexts are different enough (crisis vs multi-step wizard) that separate elements serve better, but add cross-reference noting shared ego depletion foundation

reinforcements.similarity: Both address progressive disclosure of pricing complexity
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Guest works-006 covers seasonal pricing complexity (Tier 1: simple signal, Tier 2: specific pricing, Tier 3: full comparison). Host works-006 covers mental model translation (monthly rent vs nightly rate). Both cite Kahneman on cognitive load and Norman on conceptual models. Pattern: accept input in user's native format, translate behind scenes, show both formats for verification.
reinforcements.recommendation: merge - Create unified pricing information architecture element covering both progressive disclosure (guest seasonal complexity) and format translation (host monthly/nightly) as complementary approaches to same problem

reinforcements.similarity: Both create tiered information hierarchies: guest has 3-tier disclosure, host has single-sum financial display
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Guest communicates-002: Three-tier seasonal pricing disclosure (listing→proposal→rescheduling). Host communicates-002: Single total before breakdown (monthly rent→conversion line→itemized breakdown). Both cite Kahneman's bat-and-ball problem and cognitive load constraints. Pattern: show simplified anchor first, detailed complexity on-demand.
reinforcements.recommendation: merge - Consolidate as 'Progressive Financial Disclosure Architecture' with tier structure from guest element and single-sum principle from host element

reinforcements.similarity: Spatial layout for conceptual model communication (replacement vs addition) mirrors host's anchor-then-advance pattern
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Guest looks-002: Left-right spatial mapping for replacement (arrow) vs addition (plus). Host communicates-001: Open every screen with what host already knows before new input. Both cite Norman on natural mapping and spatial correspondence. Pattern: position conveys meaning without reading.
reinforcements.recommendation: extension - Guest element extends spatial natural mapping from temporal (what came before) to conceptual (operational distinction). Add cross-reference.

reinforcements.similarity: Five-stage asynchronous feedback addresses same immediacy principle that host works-003 applies to platform vs phone speed
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Guest behaves-001: Separate instant acknowledgment (< 1s) from delayed decision (hours/days) with progressive status updates. Host works-003: Match platform cognitive speed to conversational speed (7 seconds speech = 15 seconds platform input). Both cite Norman's 0.1 second feedback threshold. Pattern: instant response even when final outcome requires time.
reinforcements.recommendation: keep_both - Applications are sufficiently distinct (async waiting vs input speed), but note shared foundation in Norman's immediacy principle

reinforcements.existing_element_id: N/A (emotional pattern novel to guest journey)
reinforcements.similarity: Crisis-to-certainty emotional arc addresses urgency absent from host journey evaluation phase
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Guest feels-001: Crisis (housing insecure) → anxiety (waiting) → relief (approved) → gratitude. Target emotion: RELIEVED. No equivalent host element because host evaluation is business decision (not crisis). However, host works-005 identifies advisor moment as commitment lock, which is also emotional transition (evaluator → contributor). Pattern: emotional state shifts drive engagement.
reinforcements.recommendation: extension - Guest crisis arc is new pattern. Host lacks crisis moments but has commitment moments. Both represent emotional inflection points in journey.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address human-to-digital trust transfer through continuity
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Guest feels-006: Warm competence through Bryant's name/photo on platform, conversation references, warm visual language. Host works-004: Continuity priming from call to platform, agent mentions platform during call, first screen references call. Both cite Norman's system image and Kahneman's priming. Pattern: digital inherits trust from human through explicit connection.
reinforcements.recommendation: merge - Consolidate as cross-journey 'Human-to-Digital Trust Continuity' element covering both priming (host) and visual/verbal continuity (guest)

contradictions.conflict: Guest works-003 assumes replacement vs addition models must be presented as explicit choice. Host works-005 says never ask host to select 'lease style' from dropdown—infer from natural description.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: Guest (Nneka call): 'Replacing: Brad swaps dates. Adding: Brad books additional nights. Different pricing.' Platform must show two explicit paths for guest to choose. Host (Andreas call): Andreas describes rental arrangement in natural speech; platform infers periodic tenancy. 'DO NOT ask host to select lease style from dropdown.'
contradictions.recommendation: Resolve by clarifying: GUEST selects operational mode (replace vs add) because it affects their immediate action and pricing. HOST does not select lease style because it's a legal/structural classification inferred from their business model description. Different contexts, no actual contradiction.

contradictions.existing_element_id: N/A (but implies different approach than host simplification)
contradictions.conflict: Guest communicates-007 proposes dual-path for expert vs novice users. Host elements consistently simplify for all users without expertise-based paths.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: Guest: 'After 3 listings viewed, prompt to switch to expert mode with less explanatory text.' Host: Consistent simplification without adaptive paths—translation happens for all hosts (works-006), defaults protect all hosts (works-002). Host design assumes all hosts are depleted and need simplified path.
contradictions.recommendation: Clarify that guest dual-path addresses repeat users across multiple bookings over months. Host simplification addresses single-session depletion within listing wizard. Different time scales. Guest expertise develops across journey; host depletion occurs within session. No contradiction if scoped correctly.

extensions.gap_filled: Crisis-optimized design for urgent rescheduling. Host journey has no crisis moments—all decisions are deliberate business evaluations with days/weeks of consideration.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Nneka call explicitly frames rescheduling as crisis ('I can't make it'), and Norman's research specifically addresses designing for 'when things go wrong.' This is genuine gap: host journey lacks time-pressure scenarios.

extensions.gap_filled: Opportunity cost feedback for invisible system consequences. Host journey has visible consequences (payment guarantee, credit checks, listing visibility). Guest rescheduling creates invisible host impacts (blocked dates, seasonal pricing, opportunity cost).
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Host works elements focus on translation and simplification but don't address making system mechanics visible to users. Guest element introduces transparency pattern: show consequence of action before action committed.

extensions.gap_filled: Predictive approval feedback before request submission. Host journey has no equivalent because host doesn't submit requests—host creates listings and responds to proposals. Predictive feedback pattern is response to async delay problem.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium-high confidence. Novel pattern but well-grounded in Norman's immediacy principle and Nneka call evidence showing hours/days wait for host decision creates anxiety.

extensions.gap_filled: Transparent empowerment through consequence visibility. Target emotion: INFORMED. Host journey targets ASSURED (works-004 trust bridge) and advisor mode (works-005) but not explicitly INFORMED as emotional outcome.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Guest element introduces emotional outcome (feeling informed/empowered) distinct from host emotions (feeling assured, engaged as advisor). Represents different value proposition: guest needs understanding of constraints, host needs confidence in process.

extensions.gap_filled: Multi-stage visual status indicators for asynchronous processes. Host journey has no async waiting periods—wizard steps are synchronous, proposals appear as notifications not pending requests.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Genuine gap. Host interaction is immediate (form submission, page navigation). Guest interaction involves human decision delay (host reviewing rescheduling request). Visual progress indicator pattern is response to delay.

extensions.gap_filled: Seasonal pricing calendar heatmap. Host elements address pricing translation (monthly→nightly) but not temporal pricing variation visualization. Guest needs to see seasonal patterns; host sets prices without visualizing seasonal demand.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium-high confidence. Extension rather than contradiction. Host pricing is input (what do you charge?). Guest pricing is discovery (what will I pay when?). Different needs justify different visualizations.

extensions.gap_filled: Continuous calendar state feedback during date selection. Host listing wizard doesn't have interactive calendar—host enters availability as schedule, not by selecting dates from picker.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Guest date selection is exploratory (which dates work? what do they cost?). Host availability setting is declarative (I'm available Mon-Thu). Interaction patterns genuinely different.

extensions.gap_filled: Delight through effortless problem resolution. Target emotion: DELIGHTED. Host journey targets engagement (advisor mode) and assurance (trust bridge) but not delight.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. May reflect difference in journey stakes: host is making business decision (rational, measured), guest is solving urgent problem (emotional, stressful). Delight is appropriate for crisis resolution, not business process completion.

extensions.gap_filled: Respectful simplification through progressive complexity. Target emotion: RESPECTED. Related to feels-002 (INFORMED) but distinct: informed = understands system, respected = platform treats user as capable adult.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium-high confidence. Host journey emphasizes competence (advisor mode, works-005) but doesn't explicitly target 'feeling respected' as emotional outcome. Guest element introduces progressive disclosure as respect mechanism—show complexity when relevant, not hide it or dump it.

token_compliance.recommendation: All new tokens follow existing token naming conventions (component-property-descriptor pattern). Most are sizing/spacing tokens extending existing system. Animation tokens (easing-spring, animation-instant) are new categories but well-justified by Norman's 0.1s feedback threshold and taste model animation philosophy. Calendar and illustration tokens are component-specific. APPROVE all new tokens with note: animation tokens should be added to global tokens.json as they apply across components.

journey_emotion_map.notes: Guest journey starts at search, not discovery (no Bryant call equivalent). Discovery is host-only phase.
Elements address discoverability of flexibility but don't explicitly target emotional state. Search emotions are implicit (hopeful about finding right listing).
Strong coverage. Multiple elements target INFORMED and CONFIDENT emotions through transparency and progressive disclosure. Aligns with evaluation phase goals.
Elements address clarity through feedback and competence through responsiveness. Good alignment with phase emotions.
HEAVY coverage. Negotiation is crisis moment in guest journey, receives most design attention. Emotions: RELIEVED, INFORMED, DELIGHTED, SUPPORTED. Strong alignment.
Journey context explicitly states acceptance phase not addressed by Nneka lens (lines 156-167). Gap in emotional coverage.
Journey context states move-in not addressed by lens (lines 170-183). Gap in emotional coverage.

Strong coverage. Active lease is where rescheduling crises occur. Elements target RELIEVED, INFORMED, DELIGHTED emotions. Alignment good but note: active lease also needs baseline 'satisfied' for non-crisis periods—not just crisis support.

arc_conflicts: Negotiation and active_lease target crisis emotions (RELIEVED, DELIGHTED) but acceptance and move_in are missing entirely. Creates arc discontinuity: evaluation → proposal → [CRISIS] negotiation → [MISSING] acceptance → [MISSING] move_in → [CRISIS] active_lease. Arc feels bipolar: calm phases then crisis phases with gaps between.
Search and listing_evaluation target INFORMED/CONFIDENT but proposal_creation shifts to CAPABLE/CLEAR without emotional bridge. Minor: these are compatible emotions but shift feels abrupt.
feels-006 (WELCOMED) targets discovery/onboarding phases, but guest journey starts at search per journey context. Emotion placement may be misaligned with actual journey entry point.
emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: Overall arc is CRISIS-HEAVY. 80% of elements address negotiation/active_lease crisis moments. 20% address evaluation/proposal calm moments. Acceptance and move_in phases entirely missing creates emotional discontinuity. Recommendation: Nneka lens reveals crisis pain points (good) but future lenses should address calm-state emotions (satisfaction during active lease, excitement at move-in, relief at acceptance) to create complete emotional journey.

discovery.notes: Guest journey context states discovery not addressed by Nneka lens because call is with host managing guest, not guest discovering platform. feels-006 may be misplaced—targets discovery but guest enters at search phase.

search.notes: All three elements address same core problem: rescheduling flexibility invisible during search. Moderate coverage of single issue.

listing_evaluation.notes: Comprehensive coverage. Addresses signifiers, conceptual models, progressive disclosure, spatial layout, seasonal pricing, expertise levels, illustrations, emotional respect.

proposal_creation.notes: Strong coverage of feedback, responsiveness, expertise adaptation, continuous calendar interaction.

negotiation.notes: DOMINANT phase. 50% of all guest elements address negotiation. Crisis design, consequence visibility, asynchronous feedback, predictive approval, emotional arcs.

acceptance.notes: Journey context lines 156-167: 'This lens does not directly address the acceptance phase.' CRITICAL GAP.

move_in.notes: Journey context lines 170-183: 'This lens does not directly address move-in.' CRITICAL GAP.

active_lease.notes: Strong coverage but CRISIS-ONLY. Elements address rescheduling breakdown, policy changes, opportunity cost revelation. Missing: baseline active lease satisfaction, routine interactions, non-crisis touchpoints.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: Journey context correctly identifies that Nneka lens does not address acceptance or move_in phases. However, coverage_map analysis reveals these are CRITICAL GAPS in emotional arc continuity.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: For next lens selection: Prioritize guest calls or book extracts that reveal acceptance moments (guest commits to host's counter-terms) and move_in experiences (first night in space, access/logistics, host greeting). Current lens focuses on rescheduling crisis; need lens showing calm-state guest satisfaction and phase transitions between proposal acceptance and active lease.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: works-001 reinforces host works-001 but creates potential merge burden. Both identify System 1 trust gates at phase transitions but in different journey contexts.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Consider consolidating guest works-001 and host works-001 into single cross-journey element 'System 1 Trust Gate at Every Phase Transition' with guest-specific (rescheduling signifiers) and host-specific (continuity priming) sub-patterns. Reduces element count, increases coherence.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: communicates-007 (dual-path expert/novice) contradicts host approach of universal simplification. Needs resolution or explicit scoping.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Clarify whether dual-path expertise applies to guest journey only (repeat users across months) vs host journey (single-session depletion). If guest-only, document as guest-specific pattern. If intended for both journeys, revisit host elements to explain why host doesn't get expertise path.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: looks elements introduce 30 new tokens. Most are justified but animation tokens (easing-spring, animation-instant, etc.) should be global, not component-specific.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Promote animation tokens from looks-007 to global tokens.json: animation-instant (80ms), animation-settle (400ms), animation-transition (200ms), easing-spring (cubic-bezier). These apply across components and reinforce taste model animation philosophy (fast response, gentle settle).

loop_back_recommendations.reason: feels-006 (WELCOMED) targets discovery/onboarding but guest journey context states guest enters at search, not discovery. Emotion placement may be misaligned.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Verify guest journey entry point. If guest enters at search (no Bryant call), feels-006 should target search→listing_evaluation transition instead of discovery→onboarding. Alternatively, if Bryant DOES call guests (not just hosts), update journey context to reflect guest discovery phase.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: Emotional arc is crisis-heavy (negotiation + active_lease = 80% of elements) with acceptance and move_in entirely missing. Creates arc discontinuity.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Next lens should target calm-state emotions: satisfaction during routine active lease interactions, excitement at move_in, relief at acceptance. Current elements cover crisis resolution (RELIEVED, DELIGHTED) but miss baseline contentment (SATISFIED, SECURE) during non-crisis periods.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: works-003 (replacement vs addition conceptual model) conflicts with host works-005 (never ask host to select lease style). Needs resolution.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Clarify distinction: Guest selects operational mode (replace my dates vs add more dates) because it affects immediate action and pricing. Host does not select lease style (periodic vs fixed-term) because it's legal classification inferred from business model. Different contexts, no contradiction IF scoped correctly. Document this distinction in both elements.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: behaves-001 (five-stage feedback) and behaves-005 (predictive approval) both address async delay but from different angles. Potential overlap.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Consider whether behaves-005 (predictive approval before submission) makes behaves-001 stages 2-3 (host viewing request, checking availability) less relevant. If prediction shows 'likely approved' instantly, does guest still need intermediate status updates? Clarify relationship: prediction for instant cases, five-stage for manual review cases.
